Authors:
Tanay Bose, Joseph H Hulbert, Treena I. Burgess, Trudy
Paap, Michael J Wingfield
Title:
Two new Phytophthora species from the Cape Floristic Region
of South Africa
Keywords:
Ancestral state reconstruction, Eastern Cape Province,
fynbos biome, multi-gene phylogeny, Western Cape Province
Abstract:
The microbial diversity associated with the fynbos
vegetation of the Cape Floristic Region of South Africa is largely
unidentified. Through the Cape Citizen Science programme, several
surveys were conducted between 2014-2019. One of the aims for these
surveys was to catalogue the diversity of Phytophthora species
associated with the endemic plants. Using soil and water baiting
techniques, we recovered several isolates of already described
Phytophthora species along with six isolates of Phytophthora taxon
emzansi and three isolates of an undescribed sterile
Phytophthora species. In this study, we used multi-gene phylogeny and
microscopy to describe these species. All isolates of P. emzansi sp.
nov. and P. afrocarpa sp. nov. formed monophyletic lineages within the
ITS Clade 2 and 10 respectively. Additionally, we also reconstructed the
evolution of sexuality among Phytophthora ITS Clade 10 species. This
analysis showed homothallism as the ancestral reproductive state for ITS
Clade 10 species. Heterothallism and sexual sterility are outcomes of
recent switches in the mating system. The unique biology of the
Phytophthora species described in this study allows them to thrive in
the exclusive fynbos vegetation.
